snippet: There was one feeling that many of the Middle East’s clerics, competing ethnic groups and warring sects could agree on: a sense of revulsion at the Islamic State’s latest video.
abstract: Rival groups across Middle East, including Syrian government, Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood and Al Qaeda and other competing religious sects and ethnic groups, unite in denouncing Islamic State after latest atrocity; brutality in burning Jordanian pilot First Lt Moaz al-Kasabeh to death in cage has brought rare moment of agreement in deeply divided and conflict-riven region.

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND and ANNE BARNARD
byline.contributor: Rod Nordland reported from Amman, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Reporting was contributed by David D. Kirkpatrick from Cairo, Ranya Kadri from Amman, Mohammad Ghannam and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Ceylan Yeginsu from Istanbul, and Jeremy W. Peters from Washington.

lead_paragraph: There was one feeling that many of the Middle East’s clerics, competing ethnic groups and warring sects could agree on: a sense of revulsion at the Islamic State’s latest video.

headline.main: Militants’ Killing of Jordanian Pilot Unites the Arab World in Anger
headline.print_headline: Militants’ Killing of Jordanian Pilot Unites the Arab World in Anger

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
